title: Lopevi
meta_title: Lopevi Volcano — Eruption History, Facts & Hazards | VolcanoAtlas
meta_description: Lopevi is a 1,413 m active stratovolcano in Vanuatu, one of the archipelago's most active volcanoes with 32 eruptions. Explore its history and hazards.

quick_answer.what: Lopevi (locally known as Vanei Vollohulu) is a small, conical island stratovolcano rising to 1,413 m (4,636 ft) in the central Vanuatu archipelago, southwestern Pacific.
quick_answer.status: Active — last confirmed eruption in 2007. One of Vanuatu's most active volcanoes with 32 recorded eruptions since 1863.
quick_answer.famous_for: Frequent explosive eruptions and lava flows that have twice forced evacuation of the island (1939 and 1960), leaving it uninhabited since the 1960s.
quick_answer.danger_level: Moderate — the island is uninhabited, but eruptions can generate pyroclastic flows and lava flows reaching the sea, and ash threatens aviation and neighboring islands.

key_facts_box.summit_crater: Small summit crater with cinder cone, breached NW

overview.content: Lopevi, known locally as Vanei Vollohulu, is a small but vigorously active stratovolcano forming a conical island approximately 7 km wide in the central Vanuatu archipelago in the southwestern Pacific Ocean. Rising to 1,413 m (4,636 ft), the basaltic-to-andesitic volcano is one of Vanuatu's most active volcanoes, with 32 recorded eruptions since 1863 — a frequency rivaled in the archipelago only by Ambrym and Yasur. Lopevi's eruptions are characteristically moderate explosive events (VEI 2–3) accompanied by lava flows that frequently reach the coast, primarily along a dominant NW-SE fissure that cuts across the island. The volcano's activity has been consequential enough to force the permanent evacuation of its population: major eruptions in 1939 and 1960 led to the island being abandoned, and Lopevi has remained uninhabited since. The 1960 eruption from a NW-flank fissure vent was particularly significant, producing a pyroclastic flow that swept to the sea and a lava flow that built a new peninsula on the western coast. Despite being uninhabited, Lopevi remains a hazard to the neighboring island of Paama approximately 10 km to the northwest, to regional aviation, and to fishing communities in the central Vanuatu waters. The volcano lies within the Vanuatu Volcanic Arc, generated by the eastward subduction of the Australian Plate beneath the Pacific Plate along the New Hebrides Trench, part of the broader Ring of Fire.

geology_and_formation.content: Lopevi sits within the Vanuatu (formerly New Hebrides) Volcanic Arc, generated by the northeastward subduction of the Indo-Australian Plate beneath the Pacific Plate along the New Hebrides Trench. The arc extends approximately 1,200 km from the Torres Islands in the north to Matthew and Hunter Islands in the south, producing a chain of volcanic islands including Ambrym, Lopevi, and Yasur on Tanna. Lopevi's basaltic to picro-basaltic composition reflects relatively primitive magmas rising through the intermediate-thickness (15–25 km) island arc crust. The volcano is constructed as a near-symmetrical cone when viewed from the sea, though the summit area is more complex: a small summit crater containing a cinder cone is breached to the northwest. An older, larger crater rim partially encircles this younger cone. The dominant NW-SE trending fissure that cuts across the island controls the location of most flank eruptions, with vents opening at various elevations along this structural lineament. Historical lava flows have extended down the slopes to the coast on multiple occasions, building new coastal land and modifying the island's outline. The southwestern coast bears evidence of repeated flow emplacement, while the northwestern flank hosts the 1960 and 1963 eruptive features.

eruption_history_overview.content: Lopevi's 32 recorded eruptions since 1863 make it one of the most frequently active volcanoes in the southwestern Pacific. The eruption record shows remarkably consistent activity: moderate Strombolian to Vulcanian explosions accompanied by lava flows, with eight eruptions reaching VEI 3. Activity has occurred at both the summit crater and from flank fissure vents, primarily along the NW-SE structural trend. The 19th century saw relatively sporadic activity (1863, 1864, 1874, 1883–1884, 1892–1893, 1898), while the 20th century was extraordinarily active, particularly the period from 1939 to 1982 during which Lopevi erupted at least 17 times — nearly continuously by volcanic standards. The early 21st century maintained this pace with eruptions in 1998–2000, 2001, 2003, 2004, 2005 (two events), 2007, and a possible uncertain eruption in 2014. The consistency of Lopevi's eruptive behavior makes it an excellent natural laboratory for studying moderate-scale arc volcanism.

subsections.title: The 1864 Eruption — First Major Recorded Event
subsections.content: On June 9, 1864, Lopevi produced its first significant recorded eruption, reaching VEI 3. This eruption followed a VEI 2 event the previous year and demonstrated that the volcano was capable of substantial explosive activity. Historical accounts from European navigators and missionaries in the New Hebrides described vigorous explosive activity and likely lava emission. The 1864 event established Lopevi's characteristic eruption style: moderate explosions accompanied by effusive lava flows, a pattern that would repeat dozens of times over the following 150 years.

subsections.title: The 1939 Eruptions — First Evacuation
subsections.content: In February and November 1939, Lopevi erupted twice from NW and SE flank fissures, both reaching VEI 2. The eruptions produced lava flows and explosive activity sufficient to threaten the small population living on the island. The February eruption originated from the northwest and southeast flanks simultaneously, while the November event affected the northwest and/or southwest flanks. The combined impact of these eruptions made continued habitation untenable, and the island's population was evacuated — the first of two evacuations that would eventually lead to Lopevi's permanent abandonment.

subsections.title: The 1960 Eruption — Island Abandoned, New Peninsula Built
subsections.content: On July 10, 1960, Lopevi produced one of its most significant eruptions at VEI 3, originating from a fissure vent on the northwestern flank at approximately 640 m elevation. The eruption generated a pyroclastic flow that swept down the NW flank to the sea — a particularly dangerous event demonstrating that Lopevi's eruptions could produce fast-moving density currents as well as lava flows. Simultaneously, a substantial lava flow descended the western slope and entered the ocean, building a new peninsula that extended the island's coastline. This eruption, combined with the 1939 events, led to the permanent evacuation of Lopevi's remaining inhabitants, who were relocated to neighboring Paama Island. The island has remained uninhabited since.

subsections.title: The 1963–1969 Period — Sustained Multi-Year Activity
subsections.content: From 1963 to 1969, Lopevi entered a period of nearly continuous eruption, with activity recorded from summit, NW, north, east, and SE flank vents. The 1963–1965 eruption (VEI 3) and the 1967–1969 eruption (VEI 3) produced both explosive activity and lava flows. Vents opened at multiple points along the dominant NW-SE fissure, with lava reaching the coast from various directions. This sustained multi-year activity confirmed Lopevi as one of the most persistently active volcanic centers in Vanuatu and justified the decision to permanently abandon the island.

subsections.title: The 1998–2003 Eruptions — Modern Activity Cluster
subsections.content: Lopevi experienced a concentrated burst of activity between 1998 and 2003, with eruptions in 1998–2000 (VEI 3), 2001 (VEI 3), and 2003 (VEI 3). The 1998–2000 eruption originated from the 1963 crater on the NW flank at approximately 1,000 m elevation and produced lava flows that descended the northwestern slope. The 2001 eruption came from a lower NW flank fissure at 200–400 m elevation, while the 2003 eruption's exact vent location is less well documented. This cluster of VEI 3 events demonstrated that Lopevi remained fully capable of significant eruptions despite decades without a large resident population to observe activity directly.

current_status_and_monitoring.content: Lopevi has been quiet since the April 2007 eruption, with an uncertain report of possible activity in December 2014. The volcano's uninhabited status means that ground-based monitoring is limited, and surveillance relies primarily on satellite-based thermal monitoring (MODIS and VIIRS), reports from passing ships and aircraft, and observations from neighboring Paama Island. The Vanuatu Meteorology and Geo-Hazards Department (VMGD) is the responsible monitoring agency. Given Lopevi's historical eruption frequency of approximately one event every two to five years during active phases, the current quiet period of nearly two decades is notable. However, similar pauses have occurred in the volcano's record before (1908–1922, 1922–1933), and volcanologists consider a return to activity likely.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: Because Lopevi is uninhabited, the direct risk to human life is lower than for many active volcanoes. However, several hazards extend beyond the island itself. Pyroclastic flows reaching the sea, as occurred in 1960, could generate localized tsunami affecting nearby islands. Ashfall from VEI 2–3 eruptions can reach Paama Island (population ~3,000), approximately 10 km to the northwest, affecting agriculture and water supplies. Volcanic ash plumes pose hazards to regional aviation, with flights between Vanuatu's islands potentially disrupted. Fishing communities operating in the waters around Lopevi face risks from ballistic projectiles, pyroclastic flows, and lava entry into the sea. Lava flows reaching the ocean produce explosive interactions (littoral explosions) and toxic laze (volcanic haze of hydrochloric acid and steam). A major eruption with substantial ash production could affect the broader central Vanuatu region, where subsistence agriculture forms the basis of livelihoods.

geography_and_physical_description.content: Lopevi is a near-conical island approximately 7 km across, rising steeply from the ocean floor to 1,413 m (4,636 ft). The island's symmetrical profile is broken by the NW-SE trending fissure system that controls most flank eruptions, and by the accumulated lava flows that have built up the western coast. The summit hosts a small crater containing a cinder cone, breached to the northwest, within the remnant of a larger older crater. The island's slopes are steep, typically 25–35 degrees, with dense tropical vegetation on the lower flanks transitioning to barren volcanic rock on the upper slopes and areas of recent lava flows. Coastal areas vary between sandy beaches, rocky cliffs, and fresh lava deltas built by historical flows entering the sea. The 1960 lava flow peninsula on the western coast is a prominent coastal feature. The island lies in the Shepherd Islands group, between the larger islands of Épi to the south and Paama and Ambrym to the north.

climate_and_global_impact.content: Lopevi's eruptions have been too small to produce measurable global climate effects. Even the VEI 3 events, while significant locally, inject insufficient sulfur dioxide and ash into the stratosphere to alter hemispheric temperatures. The volcano's impact is regional, with ashfall occasionally affecting agriculture on Paama Island and disrupting inter-island flights. In the context of southwestern Pacific volcanism, Lopevi's eruptions are comparable in scale and frequency to Yasur on Tanna and the various vents of Ambrym — consistent, moderate-scale activity driven by the active Vanuatu subduction zone.

cultural_significance.content: Lopevi holds cultural significance for the ni-Vanuatu people of the central islands, particularly the displaced communities of Paama who trace their ancestry to the island. The local name Vanei Vollohulu reflects the volcano's importance in indigenous place-naming traditions. Oral histories of the Paama people include accounts of eruptions and the evacuations that eventually forced permanent relocation. The loss of the island to volcanic activity is part of the lived experience of Paama communities, and some cultural ties to the land persist despite the population's physical absence. In broader Pacific Island culture, active volcanoes are often imbued with spiritual significance, seen as dwelling places of ancestral spirits or forces of nature that demand respect.

visiting_and_tourism.content: Lopevi is not a tourist destination and is uninhabited. The island has no infrastructure, and landing requires boat access from neighboring islands, typically Paama or Épi. Visits to the island are extremely rare and should only be attempted with full awareness of the volcanic hazard — Lopevi can erupt with little warning. The volcano can be viewed from the sea on boat trips between the central Vanuatu islands, and its symmetrical cone is a dramatic landmark visible from Paama and Épi. Visitors interested in Vanuatu's volcanoes are better served by the accessible Yasur volcano on Tanna, one of the world's most easily visited active volcanoes, or the dramatic lava lakes of Ambrym.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Lopevi sits in the volcanically active central section of the Vanuatu arc. Ambrym, one of the world's most active volcanoes with persistent lava lake activity, lies approximately 60 km to the north. Épi Island to the south has submarine volcanic vents. To the north beyond Ambrym, the underwater Kuwae caldera — site of a massive VEI 6 eruption around 1452 — lies between Épi and Tongoa. Further south, Yasur on Tanna Island is one of the world's most continuously active volcanoes, famous for its accessible Strombolian eruptions.

etymology.content: The name Lopevi derives from the local Melanesian language of the central Vanuatu islands. The volcano's indigenous name, Vanei Vollohulu, reflects the ni-Vanuatu naming tradition. Early European charts and accounts used various spellings including 'Lopevi' and 'Lope Vi,' which were standardized to the current form during the colonial period.

faqs.question: Is Lopevi an active volcano?
faqs.answer: Yes, Lopevi is one of Vanuatu's most active volcanoes, with 32 recorded eruptions since 1863. The most recent confirmed eruption occurred in April 2007. The volcano produces moderate explosive eruptions (VEI 2–3) accompanied by lava flows that frequently reach the coast. Although the island is uninhabited, the volcano is monitored via satellite thermal imagery and observations from neighboring islands. Volcanologists consider a return to eruptive activity likely given its historical eruption frequency.

faqs.question: Why is Lopevi uninhabited?
faqs.answer: Lopevi was permanently evacuated due to repeated volcanic eruptions. Major eruptions in 1939 forced the first evacuation, and the powerful 1960 eruption — which sent a pyroclastic flow to the sea and built a new lava peninsula — led to the permanent relocation of the island's population to neighboring Paama Island, approximately 10 km to the northwest. Since the early 1960s, the island has remained uninhabited, and the near-continuous eruptions from 1963 to 1982 confirmed that resettlement would be untenable.

faqs.question: When did Lopevi last erupt?
faqs.answer: Lopevi's most recent confirmed eruption occurred on April 21, 2007, reaching VEI 2 with explosive activity and ash emissions. There was an uncertain report of possible activity in December 2014. Prior to 2007, the volcano had been highly active, with eruptions in 1998–2000, 2001, 2003, 2004, 2005 (twice), and 2007. The current quiet period since 2007 is one of Lopevi's longer pauses, though similar gaps have occurred in the past.

faqs.question: Where is Lopevi?
faqs.answer: Lopevi is a small volcanic island in the central Vanuatu archipelago in the southwestern Pacific Ocean, at coordinates 16.507°S, 168.346°E. It lies in the Shepherd Islands group between the larger islands of Épi to the south and Paama and Ambrym to the north. Vanuatu is located approximately 1,750 km east of Australia and 500 km northeast of New Caledonia. Lopevi is accessible only by boat from neighboring islands.

faqs.question: What type of volcano is Lopevi?
faqs.answer: Lopevi is a stratovolcano, also called a composite volcano, built up of alternating layers of basaltic lava and pyroclastic material. The volcano forms a near-symmetrical conical island approximately 7 km across, rising to 1,413 m above sea level. Its basaltic to picro-basaltic composition produces relatively fluid lavas that can reach the coast, as well as moderate Strombolian to Vulcanian explosive activity. Eruptions frequently occur along a dominant NW-SE fissure system that cuts across the island.

faqs.question: How does Lopevi compare to Ambrym?
faqs.answer: Both Lopevi and Ambrym are among Vanuatu's most active volcanoes and lie in the same section of the Vanuatu arc. Ambrym is larger (1,334 m, ~35 km wide) and famous for persistent lava lakes, while Lopevi is smaller (1,413 m, ~7 km wide) with more episodic eruptions. Ambrym has over 50 recorded eruptions and a higher VEI maximum (4 vs 3), but Lopevi's 32 eruptions represent an impressive frequency for such a small island. Lopevi's eruptions tend to produce more lava flows reaching the coast, while Ambrym's activity is often concentrated at its summit calderas.
